Line 24: Line 24:
In January 2009, it had a share of 1.12% of the [[web browser]] market.<ref>{{cite news|first=Wolfgang |last=Gruener |url=http://www.tgdaily.com/content/view/40575/113/ |title=Google Chrome crosses 1% market share again |publisher=TG Daily |location=Chicago (IL) |date=2009-01-03 |accessdate=2009-01-03}}</ref> It was first released as a [[beta version]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] on September 2, 2008. The name is derived from the [[graphical user interface]] frame, or "chrome", of web browsers. The public stable release was on December 11, 2008.
In January 2009, it had a share of 1.12% of the [[web browser]] market.<ref>{{cite news|first=Wolfgang |last=Gruener |url=http://www.tgdaily.com/content/view/40575/113/ |title=Google Chrome crosses 1% market share again |publisher=TG Daily |location=Chicago (IL) |date=2009-01-03 |accessdate=2009-01-03}}</ref> It was first released as a [[beta version]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] on September 2, 2008. The name is derived from the [[graphical user interface]] frame, or "chrome", of web browsers. The public stable release was on December 11, 2008.
â
'''Chromium''' is the [[open source]] project behind Google Chrome.<ref>"Google Chrome is built with open source code from Chromium." Retrieved from: http://dev.chromium.org/developers/how-tos/getting-started.</ref> The Google-authored portion of it is released under the [[BSD license]], with other parts being subject to a variety of different permissive open-source licenses, including the [[MIT License]], the [[GNU Lesser General Public License|LGPL]], the [[Microsoft Permissive License]] and a [[Mozilla Public License|MPL]]/[[GNU General Public License|GPL]]/[[GNU Lesser General Public License|LGPL]] [[dual-licensing|tri-license]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://code.google.com/chromium/terms.html |title=Chromium Terms and Conditions |date=2008-09-02|accessdate=2008-09-03 |work=[[Google Code]]}}</ref> It implements the same feature set as Chrome, but has a slightly different logo.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/fatalexception/archives/2008/09/building_google.html|title=Building Google Chrome: A first look |last=McAllister |first=Neil |date=2008-09-11 |work=Fatal Exception |publisher=InfoWorld |accessdate=2008-09-16 |quote=As the name suggests, Chromium is a rawer, less polished version of Chrome. The UI is mostly identical, with only a few very minor visual differences...The most readily evident difference is the logo, which sheds the Google colors in favor of a subdued blue design}}</ref>
+
'''[http://code.google.com/chromium/ Chromium]''' is the [[open source]] project behind Google Chrome.<ref>"Google Chrome is built with open source code from Chromium." Retrieved from: http://dev.chromium.org/developers/how-tos/getting-started.</ref> The Google-authored portion of it is released under the [[BSD license]], with other parts being subject to a variety of different permissive open-source licenses, including the [[MIT License]], the [[GNU Lesser General Public License|LGPL]], the [[Microsoft Permissive License]] and a [[Mozilla Public License|MPL]]/[[GNU General Public License|GPL]]/[[GNU Lesser General Public License|LGPL]] [[dual-licensing|tri-license]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://code.google.com/chromium/terms.html |title=Chromium Terms and Conditions |date=2008-09-02|accessdate=2008-09-03 |work=[[Google Code]]}}</ref> It implements the same feature set as Chrome, but has a slightly different logo.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/fatalexception/archives/2008/09/building_google.html|title=Building Google Chrome: A first look |last=McAllister |first=Neil |date=2008-09-11 |work=Fatal Exception |publisher=InfoWorld |accessdate=2008-09-16 |quote=As the name suggests, Chromium is a rawer, less polished version of Chrome. The UI is mostly identical, with only a few very minor visual differences...The most readily evident difference is the logo, which sheds the Google colors in favor of a subdued blue design}}</ref>
